depoLine.text: HYLAND: All right, it's July 23 at 308. Lacy Hyland,
Robert Bonzo, Matt Breaker, Martin Nielsen.
BRAKER: And Martin just got here and he asked a question
about the computers that had been seized and there was
material in the Lake district court called GDPR. And he
wants to know how is that going to be protected and
stored by the county so that. That when he gets it back,
it's still usable to him. And secrets are not divulged
from the companies.
NIELSEN: Yeah. And it doesn't violate the GDPR act of
Europe because if an american company has even one
employee in Europe, they have to be 100% compliant on the
side according to the law.
BRAKER: And I'm going to. I don't know the answer to
these questions, so I'm going to do my best to find them
out today and then tell you. And then when we're done,
we're going to go over. You're going to make a call in a
couple minutes, recorded call to Ziegler from the SAB.
And I'm going to. I wanted to touch base with you on some
of the topics of that and hear your thoughts on that.
Sure. So, you know, one would be to discuss the upcoming
$45,000 payment, the amount of the money. Who does the
check get made out to?
NIELSEN: So I don't know yet until I made the phone call.
BRAKER: Yeah.
NIELSEN: These are things I don't think we're gonna
cover. Yeah, yeah, no, of course.
BRAKER: Yeah. And I know they're obvious, but I just
gotta make sure.
NIELSEN: Okay. Gotcha. All right. Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Exactly.
BRAKER: Whatever you're comfortable with. But I'm hoping
that these things get out. That is the amount that the
checks.
NIELSEN: Yeah. You know, amount who has to be made out
to. What are you thinking about buying for it or, you
know. Yeah.
BRAKER: Okay, well, who do you deliver? Who do you
deliver it to?
NIELSEN: Yeah.
BRAKER: Would you be asking him if he knows what the
arrangement is? The deal is that you've got. With. Your
company's got the sheriff.
NIELSEN: So I don't know what JJ, obviously, what they
have communicated on the back end, but I just want to
say, hey, I mean, JJ told me to call, so I assume you
know, you know what this is about, or, I mean, sorry,
whatever, but I highly doubt that JJ have actually told
him, like, what it's for, to that. To that nature.
BRAKER: Okay. But you'll do some little exploration
because.
NIELSEN: This guy is just in charge of that.
BRAKER: And then maybe some talk about. So that'll talk
about JJ, but you're also gonna talk about who's gonna
communicate with JJ, that this call is made, that you'll
take responsibility for talking to JJ afterwards, or is
he gonna.
NIELSEN: Yeah, yeah. I'll tell him all the point of
contact for this going back and forth, and I'll give him
the. My 650 number for future communication. Okay, that
sounds good.
BRAKER: Okay.
NIELSEN: Whatever. Excuse.
BRAKER: Anything else you guys think he should be trying
to touch on?
HYLAND: Wow.
BRAKER: Okay. Can I. Before the call is made, can I just
ask just a few quick ones just to circle back from the
other day, because I want to make sure I understood
things. Is that all right with you?
NIELSEN: Yes.
BRAKER: Okay. So you. We had gone through the texts that
were found on the phone, on your phone the other day, and
I have a couple of them here. We sort of touched on them,
but I got one here that says, well, let me just start
with this. So when we talked yesterday, we went through
these. I then went back afterwards, and the date of the
primary for the sheriff's race was on June 5. I now know
that that's the specific date of it. So when we look at
your text, the first one was May 29. Got a second quick
call from Martin. Then June 4 4th, talking about trying
to hook up. But then after the primary, your next text is
this one a week later on June 12, in which you say. You
talk about some other stuff, but then you say, also, I
saw the quote, results, close quote.
NIELSEN: Oh, yeah. That was probably off the primary that
she won or she did whatever. Runoff or whatever she has
to do at that point.
BRAKER: Okay. So that's what that results is talking
about, the primary. Yeah.
NIELSEN: I mean, that's what comes to my mind right now.
BRAKER: Okay. And then you say.
NIELSEN: Cause we didn't. I mean, obviously, she was up
for election when we got this thing started. Right. So if
somebody else had won, then we probably didn't have this
avenue. Right. So I'm sure I kept an eye on what was
going on election wise.
BRAKER: Understood. Okay. And then you said, so we should
connect on that when you have time. And you sort of just
answered it. But the. That is what.
NIELSEN: Yeah, probably like the result that she actually
made it to whatever.
BRAKER: The runoffs.
NIELSEN: Yeah, runoffs.
BRAKER: But what about. What is that? And you're sort of
already answering, but what does that mean for you, what
your plan was?
NIELSEN: Well, I think at one point, Ryan, I think I was
probably alluded to, if she didn't win, we couldn't get
this thing done because it would be a different sheriff,
and then JJ wouldn't be in the position that he's in
since he was like her. Whatever. Right. Hand man or
something to that nature.
BRAKER: Okay. And just to clear up. So the other day when
we talked, then you say, then right after that, you say,
okay. You talk about connecting, then you say, okay, no
worries, I'll reach out next week. Things are moving.
Which we talked about meant money.
NIELSEN: Yeah. Which probably meant that I had to go back
on my side and say that we could move forward with this.
BRAKER: So there's gonna be a runoff. She's gonna need
the money.
NIELSEN: Yeah.
BRAKER: And you're already working on that, on your end,
getting some money?
NIELSEN: Yeah, I mean, whatever. The first donation and
whatever. I mean, I think it probably. At first, I
probably thought they were going to use it for posters
and stickers and whatever, right? At that point, I didn't
know I hadn't gotten that organization to write it out to
you for Laurie. Yeah.
BRAKER: Yeah. Okay, so sort of a specific question here.
At what point do you think it became clear to you that,
you know, crystal clear that if you paid money, you would
be able to get paid money to help Laurie's campaign, you
would be able to get CCWs? Was that at the end of that
first meeting was, we already got the money moving. But
are you able to tell us, you know, at what point that was
clear to you if we gave the money to the campaign? That.
NIELSEN: I mean, it was probably already back when I said
we had Mihar, Paul and JJ had that meeting where it was
kind of disgusting in numbers.
BRAKER: Okay.
NIELSEN: And then I forget what. How the text. There was
one of those texts that said, like, whatever, he was
working on it. No, no promises or something. Right. So
that must have been right in that.
BRAKER: So you think that at that meeting where you're
with JJ and you're with Harpal, where specific numbers in
terms of dollars and in terms of CCW's was discussed,
that's where it became clear to you?
NIELSEN: Yeah, I mean, that's what. I had a good feeling
about it.
BRAKER: Okay. And so you ended up writing that check,
that check to 45,000 to this package. Do you recall who
it was that told you that's the best way to help Laurie's
campaign is to give to that pack?
NIELSEN: I mean, either that pack came from. It came from
either JJ, which probably got it from shum, or it came
directly from shum. And I can't remember, like, how it
went, but, I mean, I went down to his office to talk it
off, so.
BRAKER: So you already knew before that?
NIELSEN: Yeah.
BRAKER: Okay.
NIELSEN: Yeah.
BRAKER: Okay. Was Jack aware, stronggren aware of the
donation money?
NIELSEN: I don't think he was really aware of amounts and
all that stuff. I mean, we probably mentioned that we had
to make a donation, but not like never, like any of the
detailed stuff, to my recollection. And like I said, he
never met JG. He's never been to any of the meetings. He
never sat in on anything. Whatever emails or texts that I
have going out to him saying, give me the guys, have him
fill out paperwork and give it to me. I mean, that's
pretty much his involvement.
BRAKER: So you may have. You did communicate to him that
a contribution was going to be made to get the CCW, but
the amount of it.
NIELSEN: Yeah, I don't think the amounts was mentioned or
the numbers. I mean, it was. I mean, obviously, if I come
and say I can probably make this happen now, then. Right.
It's not like the normal route that people would go to
get ccws, but.
BRAKER: Okay, now just again, you had said originally,
you know, that there was first the talk about a six
figures number.
NIELSEN: Yeah, I mean, we shot it back and forth,
obviously. Like, can we get 20? You know what I mean? And
I was like, probably like, too many. And then, okay, can,
you know, get ten?
BRAKER: Or how did we get from six figures to 90, though?
NIELSEN: Well, that's what I said. So when they came back
and said, what is that going to take? And then JJ didn't
say anything. He looked at Harpaul and Harpaul said at
like 90, you know, or 90 ish or something, it was like,
you know, to.
BRAKER: That you had lowered the number of ccws that you
wanted or needed. And once you started.
NIELSEN: Yeah, I mean, we started high. Because if you
just said yes with 20, I would have, you know, probably
said okay.
BRAKER: Right, yes.
NIELSEN: But, you know, there was an uncomfortable level
of whatever, so to speak.
HYLAND: Okay, what was the number that. Do you remember?
What was the general number that 90 would get you?
BRAKER: I'm confused.
HYLAND: You probably already said this.
NIELSEN: Yeah. So that was like the ten plus, you know,
instead of, like, starting out with the 15 or 20, you
know, but at least we were.
BRAKER: What do you think the amount would have been? I
know that you said.
NIELSEN: Yeah, so they said, yeah, so just an extra. No,
I mean, 200,000, probably up to 20. I mean, what if you
divide it up? I mean, I don't know what that is, you
know, 90 by ten or twelve or something. I mean, I don't
know, somewhere around, you know, eight, nine grand
apiece. I mean, it comes out too. But if that
statistically would continue that way or not. I mean, I'm
not sure, but, you know, 20 was too many.
BRAKER: Do you know who Jamal Shabagi is? Jamal Shabaji
Shabagi.
NIELSEN: You have a photo?
BRAKER: No.
NIELSEN: I mean, I can. I can. I can guess his ethnicity,
but.
BRAKER: How about James Toronto?
NIELSEN: No.
BRAKER: William Burns.
NIELSEN: You guys have any picture? I mean, I'm. Those
names don't ring a bell, but sometimes if I see photo,
but.
BRAKER: Jamed. Nidek.
HYLAND: James.
BRAKER: James. James Nidek. N E I d I g. I think. These
names don't mean anything to you?
NIELSEN: Yeah, he sounds like he's maybe in charge of
apple security or something now.
HYLAND: You dig that?
NIELSEN: Yeah.
BRAKER: Okay.
NIELSEN: I mean, if that's the same, how do you know?
HYLAND: How do you guys have.
NIELSEN: No, but I mean, all the. I mean, I know every
CSO at every single company up here, pretty much.
BRAKER: So Apple has its own security? Yeah, they just
hire them directly. But doesn't as have some connection
to Apple?
NIELSEN: Yeah, I think we do some of their. Like, when
they move software or devices and stuff. I think we have
some fallout cars and stuff or whatever. Or if they are
traveling overseas and they don't have enough people
themselves, we go out and do their advanced worker or
something. But they have their own team for the CEO of
Apple.
BRAKER: And you met some of those people?
NIELSEN: Yeah.
BRAKER: Okay, so that could be who James Nideg is. But
the other names. No, no, no.
NIELSEN: I mean, Jamal. No, they don't ring a bell.
BRAKER: Okay.
NIELSEN: But, I mean, I know somebody could call Jim
Nidek, but that's what I'm saying. Like, if you say James
Naughty sometimes, that's the name on the driver's
license or something like that. Yeah. So, I mean, that's
the only thing that rings a bell.
BRAKER: Okay. I think that's all I have.
HYLAND: Okay.
NIELSEN: Which obviously tells me maybe I'm not the only
one who made a deal with somebody.
BRAKER: Do you need this?
HYLAND: I do. Do you want to meet yourself?
BRAKER: Yeah. Yeah, she's coming down.
NIELSEN: Can we talk a little bit about the timeline? I
talked briefly to Lacey this morning. Like, what? And
again, I mean, if you can't tell me, obviously, but if I
don't get ahold of James today and I have to go on
vacation and, like, what is your guys. I guess. I don't
know what end point before you start either prosecuting
or you have enough. Or I'm trying to figure out, like,
it's totally fluid. Okay.
BRAKER: Hoping that you'll connect with him this week.
NIELSEN: Yeah.
BRAKER: You're leaving when?
NIELSEN: I'm leaving on Sunday morning.
BRAKER: Yeah. Hoping that happens. If that doesn't
happen, then we're gonna have to figure out what we're,
you know, another.
NIELSEN: Yeah, yeah. And again, I mean, obviously,
Benzene, keep it going as long as I have to. But it's
also, like, if I have to go meet him and I have to bring
another couple applications to turn in. I mean, those are
legit names and whatever, but I don't want to get any
more people in trouble. That has no reason to be in
trouble, because if they never turned in their apps.
Right, then, yes. No harm, no foul there. But I always
have something to keep things moving with. So, like, what
kind of, you know, guarantees or whatever do I have that
these guys don't get rolled up or. You know what I mean?
Because now I'm using them, you guys, to get your result,
so to speak.
BRAKER: Right? Yeah. Well, the applications that you
would be delivering to JJ are as employees, correct?
NIELSEN: Do they have no clue?
BRAKER: Yeah.
NIELSEN: So.
BRAKER: Okay. I don't foresee any issue with that then.
And it's not like, I don't think this is going to be
dragging out that long.
NIELSEN: Yeah, but you see what I'm getting. And, like, I
mean, if I could avoid getting, you know, depending on
how you guys look at it.
BRAKER: Right. Understood.
NIELSEN: And what was the other thing? When I call this
guy as far. Again, depending on the length of the
investigation, because obviously, I'm gonna have to give
him, like, I want to donate by. Right. So my original
thought had been by the end of July, which is not gonna
happen, and then I have my vacation, all that stuff. But
is it okay if I tell him we're thinking about doing this
in September? Does that give us, like, you guys enough
time, or. I don't want to push it too far out.
BRAKER: Is there any way you could give him the check?
NIELSEN: Well, this is July. I mean, we're. July is
running. Yeah, I mean, I'm not gonna.
BRAKER: We're not. It's not gonna happen, this.
NIELSEN: No, no, because I would have to go. Go back, and
it would have to be wire and, you know, like, all these.
BRAKER: Well.
NIELSEN: Yeah, so, you know, we have the last two weeks
of August, and plus, if it. If it ever came to that
point, then I have no other choice. But obviously, my
company and their whole staff or lawyer is gonna have to
be right. Part of it. So I was trying to see if I could
promise something for September, and then you guys are
done to that point. So it never actually happens that I
have to go give a physical check. Yes, because it becomes
a completely different picture with a $500 million backed
law firm and venture capital. I mean, it's going to be a
complete. You know.
BRAKER: Well, I'm not sure we'd have to go through all
that to give a check.
NIELSEN: Well, I can't give a check that bounces, either.
BRAKER: Well, it won't get that far.
NIELSEN: Okay. That's what I'm trying to get at. Like
what?
BRAKER: Yeah. Well. But I think you should say. Well, can
you say I try to get it to you as soon as possible, or by
probably. Probably in. I mean, we're probably not leaving
on Saturday for two weeks. As soon as I come back, I
should be able to be able to.
NIELSEN: Have this at hand, and that'll bring us to the
last two weeks of August.
BRAKER: Okay. Or could you say you're working on it?
There's a chance that. There's a small chance it could be
this week, but most likely in August. And if it was this
week, then I'm not talking about you going to your
company and getting the check. I'm just talking about
some other methods.
NIELSEN: No, I had said that I would like to get it done
in July if I could. So. He doesn't know that part because
I haven't talked to him yet.
BRAKER: So how about if we say you're working on it,
possibly get it before you go on your vacation, but if
not, it would be within a week.
NIELSEN: Or so after you return.
BRAKER: Are you. Yeah. Okay.
HYLAND: Normally, on recorded phone calls, the person
listening in will be like, coaching you. I'm not gonna do
that, because that's gonna show you off, and it's really
confusing. But you'll just see me jotting down notes, and
if something is just like.
NIELSEN: Yeah, and I would probably prefer to stare at
the wall. So I don't.
BRAKER: Yeah, actually, I'll step out, too. I hear about
it after, but. Okay.
HYLAND: But I might write, like, a word. Yeah, I'm not
gonna.
NIELSEN: So, how much who it's going to, kind of whatever
relationship with JJ. So, I believe I met this guy at one
fundraiser, like JJ said one time. You know what I mean?
I shook his hand or whatever.
BRAKER: And, you know, this is going to the advisory
board. You don't have to get into this. I'm just trying.
But what is the. What. How is the advisory board helping
her?
NIELSEN: Yeah. And that's what I was saying. I'm not. So,
for my conversations, I don't think they're actually fit.
Like, that is literally gonna help her. Correct. On the
back end. I think they're gonna buy equipment and stuff
for it.
BRAKER: Okay.
NIELSEN: But again, I mean, that's what I'm. What I'm
told. Right. So.
BRAKER: Okay, but this is. But it's your understanding
that.
NIELSEN: So everything.
BRAKER: This is what she wants in order for.
NIELSEN: Yeah. So everything we do is helping our case to
get our ccws, obviously. But if they're buying ATV's or
new radios, if she's happy with that or they're happy,
or. And again, I don't know, between JJ and her, if he's
actually going to her and say, we're going to do this or
if it's kept here. Right. I have no.
BRAKER: Understood. But am I clear that. Am I
understanding you quickly? It's your understanding that
this is what she. Laurie wants in terms of where the
money should go for you to get what you. Yeah.
NIELSEN: I mean, so again, I can't speak on her behalf,
but the information I'm getting my way is this is what I
have to do to get what I want from her people.
BRAKER: Okay. Okay. I think that's it. Good luck and
thank you. We'll be in touch.
NIELSEN: Thanks, man.
BRAKER: Okay. Thank you. All right, I guess I'm leaving.
You call me. I'll call them.
NIELSEN: Oh, do we have any service down here?
HYLAND: The obvious question.
BRAKER: Yeah, actually, when I came down and found the
place, I meant to turn my phone on to make sure I had an
id from the place.
HYLAND: What does it say on your lazy.
BRAKER: Yeah, I got. I got good service down here. I got
lt and everything. Yeah, that'd be pretty good.
NIELSEN: Yeah, it's on Lt. So you gave me this number
that doesn't go anywhere.
BRAKER: Yeah, it's supposed to be 792.
NIELSEN: 792 or. I told you it wasn't me. The.
BRAKER: Right. Yeah, but honestly, my cell number is.
HYLAND: The one that gave me a bogus.
BRAKER: Yeah. Yeah. I don't really want you calling me.
Why don't I give you my real number? Hey, uh, outside of
all this.
NIELSEN: Uh huh.
BRAKER: You doing all right?
NIELSEN: Yeah. Okay.
BRAKER: You're not freaking balls.
NIELSEN: No, I know. No, I mean, like I said, this is
kind of. I mean, I'm not gonna say it's nothing new.
BRAKER: Yeah. Yeah.
NIELSEN: Cause, like, the. Yeah, yeah. But I've been up.
BRAKER: But I just wanna make sure that your. Your head's
in a good spot, that you're good.
NIELSEN: Yeah.
BRAKER: Yeah.
NIELSEN: No, I mean, I've been exposed to low words.
BRAKER: I'm sure.
NIELSEN: But, I mean, if anything, I mean, again, I'm
helping you because obviously, I'm hoping that I'm gonna
get a return favor at the end of this so I can kind of
keep my life and my guns and my permits and not have to
flip burgers at McDonald's or whatever.
HYLAND: Right. So what is your service down here or what
bar?
NIELSEN: I have four bars. Lt. So it's probably. I did
call Jack earlier just for, like, two minutes and just
make sure that because he's.
HYLAND: Oh, did you guys speak?
NIELSEN: Yeah, yeah, I talked to him for, like, two
minutes and just say, hey, I can't really go into detail,
but just, you know, don't tell too many things to too
many people and, yeah, tell the truth. It's always, like,
the. The best option. And the way I see it, you have
nothing, you know, to worry about on your side. You just
happen to get tracked into my kind of mess and. But I
guess, you know, that you lower it up and whatever the
company provided for him and all that stuff, so I can't.
I mean, at this point. But again, I encourage them to
just tell the truth, you know what I mean? And just
whatever they ask, just give it to them because, I don't
know. I mean, for me, it doesn't affect me. Right.
BRAKER: That's just the best policy.
NIELSEN: Yeah, yeah, no, I mean, that's what I told them.
Right. So just don't freak out, don't talk, because I
already have one more space now that people know that
called him out of the blue and asked if he was okay
because they had heard he was. Was getting. You know,
that he got arrested or whatever. Right.
HYLAND: So somebody else called you and told you that?
NIELSEN: No, somebody else called him and told him that
they shouldn't even be in this conversation. Like some on
the way out skirts of nothing. Nothing. So I don't know,
saw, heard, or say. Well, I mean, I'm sure this doesn't
pop up in some kind of Nick rickshaw system or what
doesn't? Yeah, like that. Arrest, whatever. Okay.
BRAKER: No, it's all under wraps, bro.
NIELSEN: Well, as much as right now? Yeah, because, I
mean, I got another email today from our law firm that
they're like, you have to call us. And I just ignored
those, in part, so. But I have to call my CEO at some
point later today and say I'm okay, and this is what I'm
doing. And you guys just.
HYLAND: And this is. It's all totally up to you on how
you respond, but I feel like maybe it could be one option
is to downplay it by, if they have an idea of what it's
about, you could maybe address the address issue on the
applications. Oh.
NIELSEN: I mean, like I said, I mean, I was told
everybody had to be in Santa Clara county. Right. So what
address is do we have in Santa Clara county.
HYLAND: Right. But they're not necessarily home
addresses. Right. They're just addresses that were used.
So, you know, and it's something that is a concern to us.
So it might ease some nerves if people just realize that
was just addresses on the application. Just an idea.
NIELSEN: But, yeah, I mean, obviously, nobody reached out
to my company from your guys, so at this point. Right.
Which they should kind of also feel good about, I guess.
Right. That nobody has gone to them.
BRAKER: I have not contacted them.
NIELSEN: But what I'm saying is, like, they would have
probably had a search where have people call them or
whatever, like, to be part of.
BRAKER: Yeah. Basically, if your. Your company was part
of this investigation. Right. The name was reached out to
them.
NIELSEN: Yes.
BRAKER: And that hasn't happened.
NIELSEN: Yeah, exactly. Right. So in my mind, then I'll
be like, why you guys kind of freaking out for a lot of
this stuff when nobody's even contact? You said you've
done anything wrong. I mean, at least at this point.
BRAKER: Yeah.
NIELSEN: So I might just have to, like I said, call my
CFO for five minutes and say, hey, I have not, because
they think that I've refused help, and I have to explain
to them that I'm doing this out of my own free will and
going along with the process, because I feel like that's
the best thing and just be truthful with everything and
see how it works out at the end. And, you know, I don't
want to think that I have reclined lawyers and want to
represent myself.
BRAKER: Right.
NIELSEN: Because, like you said, I can say stuff at any
time. Right. So as long as I just let you guys know that
I have to make that phone call today, because it's not
gonna ignore them for days.
HYLAND: Yeah. All right, well, I say we trying. Like I
said, we're not gonna stare at you.
NIELSEN: Yeah. Do we have a. I just have his name again,
if you have. Yeah, I don't have a photo of that text or
whatever. Let me just write down.
HYLAND: This is my stuff, actually, it is. That's gonna
go to you, so you can write on that. Some of your stuff.
BRAKER: We have another bag over here that's more stuff.
HYLAND: It looked like all the valid permits I could find
besides the Santa Clara county.
NIELSEN: Yeah, but that's also a valid permit that's
issued correctly.
HYLAND: Yeah, but that's also potential evidence in this.
BRAKER: In this case.
NIELSEN: So I'll give it back to you whenever you want. I
mean, I have copies of it, and I can put a copy as long
as I have a copy of the paper when I can carry my wallet.
I mean, as long as you guys are okay with me doing my
thing.
BRAKER: You did that yourself?
